newsitem.title: UK: UK MPs say LSE moves too slow on reforms.
newsitem.headline: UK MPs say LSE moves too slow on reforms.

text.p: An influential British parliamentary committee on Wednesday accused the London Stock Exchange of dragging its feet in implementing a fully electronic order-driven based system for trading shares.
The exchange is scheduled to convert to a system that matches buy and sell orders by computer in October 1997.
"There's a suspicion that you are stalling," Treasury Select Committee member Diane Abbott told LSE chairman Gavin Casey.

Under the exchange's current quote-driven system, share prices are set by primary dealers known as marketmakers. The LSE, Europe's busiest bourse, is the only major exchange that lets marketmakers set prices.
The LSE is still thrashing out the details of the new order-driven regime. It last amended the rules for the order book last month.
Committee member Quentin Davies suggested the exchange's approach to carrying out the new system was "half-hearted," "limited" and allowed too many exceptions to the rules.
Casey, who took the helm of the exchange in June after a bitter controversy over radical reforms forced his predecessor out, denied claims that the exchange was moving too slowly.
"We have to get it right and we will get it right. There's no point in rushing," Casey told the committee during a review of the exchange's progress in modernising its market.
"It must be right to take it in stages," he added.
Initially, 40 to 50 of the FTSE 100 stocks would go through the order book, Casey said. The FTSE 250 may be added in due course, he said.
A controversial rule that allows market makers to delay reporting large block trades raised concerns among committee members that the preferential treatment would compromise market transparency.
Casey acknowledged that rules could be abused in some cases, but said they could be modified as the process continued.
He said that unless the right balance between liquidity and market transparancy was stuck, business will move elsewhere.

"We will increase transparency as long as it doesn't drive business away, he said. "I would not want to be responsible for pushing it too far too fast and watch a lot of business disappear -- once it disappears it's my opinion that it'll never come back."
But MPs appeared unwilling to accept that there is an inverse relationship between transparency and liquidity.
"Maybe more transparency would produce more liquidity," said Barry Legg, who chaired the committee.
Despite the outstanding issues facing the exchange, the LSE seems to have made some headway since the last inquiry in July, Davies told Reuters after the meeting.

"I thought there was a renewed spirit there. They seem to acknowledge problems they previously were not willing to acknowledge," Davies said. "They are making progress, but it's slow." -- London newsroom +44-171-542-4026
